paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: Extracted information on the KCNH2 gene variant A561P, including penetrance data and individual records.

patients.demographics: Patient: 22 years old, male; Mother: 46 years old, female
patients.phenotype: Patient presented syncope and torsades de pointes arrhythmia; Mother was asymptomatic with a normal ECG

individual_records.phenotype_details: Presented syncope and torsades de pointes arrhythmia
individual_records.evidence_sentence: The patient carries a missense mutation in the KCNH2 gene, encoding the HERG K+ channel α-subunit, causing an alanine-to-proline substitution at position 561.

individual_records.phenotype_details: No clinical symptoms and a normal ECG
individual_records.evidence_sentence: As a control, somatic cells from a urine sample were also obtained from the patient’s mother, aged 46 years, who had no clinical symptoms and a normal ECG and who was negative for the KCNH2 mutation.

functional_data.summary: The mutation led to a trafficking defect that resulted in reduced delayed rectifier K+ current (IKr), causing action potential prolongation and arrhythmias.

variants.segregation_data: The variant segregates with disease in the family; the patient is affected while the mother is unaffected.
variants.evidence_level: strong evidence based on functional assays and segregation data
variants.additional_notes: The study highlights the use of UhiPS cells to model the electrophysiological characteristics of the KCNH2 mutation.
key_quotes: This phenotype gave rise to action potential prolongation and arrhythmias.
Comparison of HERG expression from the patient’s UhiPS-CMs to the mother’s UhiPS-CMs showed that the mutation led to a trafficking defect.

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data regarding the KCNH2 variant A561P was successfully extracted.
